resources.string: One of the most valuable commercial freshwater species in the northwest, the Northern Pike is a strong, persistent fighter attracting many fishermen because of the challenge it presents.

-Large, elongated body. 

-Dark green to brown body with light, yellowish or white spots. 

-Dark back fades to creamy white belly. 

-Fully scaled cheek and partially scaled gill cover. 

-10 pores on underside of lower jaw.

-Length: 45-75 centimetres (18-30 inches) 

-Weight: 0.9-4.3 kilograms (2-9.5 pounds) 

-Ontario Record: 19.1 kilograms (42.1 pounds)

As a cool-water species, the Northern Pike\'s habitat consists of slow, heavily vegetated rivers or the weedy bays of lakes. During the height of the summer, the Northern Pike can be found in deep water to avoid high temperatures.
The most popular game fish in North America, the Largemouth Bass are sought after for their vigorous resistance.

-Back and sides are green to olive. 

-Broken Horizontal stripe along body. 

-Large, wide lower jaw slightly longer than upper jaw. 

-Two joined dorsal fins, separation more obvious than Smallmouth Bass.

-Length: 25-55 centimetres (10-22 inches) 

-Weight 0.7-1.8 kilograms (1.5-4 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 4.7 kilograms (10.4 pounds)

The Largemouth Bass can be found in the upper levels of warm water of small, shallow lakes or bays. It is almost always found close to soft bottoms, stumps and in a variety of sub-emergent and emergent vegetation, especially waterlilies, cattails and pond weeds.
The Yellow Perch is a freshwater fish with an almost circumpolar distribution in the northern hemisphere and is both a important recreational and commercial fish species.

-An elongate, oval body. 

-Two well-separated dorsal fins. 

-6 to 8 dark, vertical bands on side. 

-Light yellow body with white underside. 

-Large mouth, extending to below the middle of the eye.

-Length: 15-30 centimetres (6-12 inches) 

-Weight: 0.35 kilograms (0.75 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 1.1 kilograms (2.4 pounds)
The Yellow Perch is a cool-water species and is most abundant in the open water of lakes with moderate vegetation, clear water and bottoms of muck, sand or gravel.
The Walleye is a perch like fish with a keen eyesight. The oldest reported age for a Walleye is 29.

-Large, elongated body. 

-Back is olive-green to brown; side paler with yellow flecks. 

-White tip on lower tail fin. 

-Large teeth. 

-Spiny and soft dorsal fins are separated.

-Typical length: 35.5-58.4 centimetres (14-23 inches) 

-Typical weight: 0.68-1.36 kilograms (1.5-3 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 10.1 kilograms (22.3 pounds)
Walleye are large predators adapted to low light and are found in large, shallow turbid lakes and the deeper waters of clear lakes.
The Muskellunge is a large freshwater fish that can reach speeds of up to 48 kilometres per hour and can live for as long as 30 years.

-Very large, elongated body. 

-Dark vertical bands on light background, at time spotted or clear. 

-Beige to white belly. 

-Partially scaled cheek and gill cover. 

-12â€“18 pores on underside of lower jaw.

-Length: 71-137 centimetres (28-40 inches) 

-Weight: 4-11 kilograms (8-23 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 29.5 kilograms (65.0 pounds)
Muskellunge inhabit clear vegetated lakes, quiet pools, and the backwater of creeks and small to large rivers.
The Rock Bass is a freshwater fish native to east-central North America with its defining characteristic being a large red eye.

-Small and deep-bodied. 

-Large, red eye. 

-Adults have regular rows of spots along the side. 

-Back and upper sides are brown to olive. 

-Dorsal fin has 10 to 13 spines.

-Length: 15-20 centimetres (6-8 inches) 

-Weight: 0.2 kilograms (0.4 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 1.4 kilograms (3.0 pounds)
Rock Bass prefer clear, rocky and vegetated stream pools and lake margins. Rock Bass can also commonly be seen swimming with other sunfish and bass.
The White Crappie is a moderately large, fresh water fish that has a deep, slightly longer body than a black crappie.

-Six dorsal fin spines. 

-6 or 7 anal fin spines. 

-Side of the body has faint vertical bars.

-Length: 20-30 centimetres (8-12 inches) 

-Weight: 0.1 - 0.23 kilograms (0.25 - 0.5 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 1.26 kilograms (2.78 pounds)
The White Crappie resides in the mouths of small creeks or streams and in weedy, sheltered bays.
The Common Carp is a fish that is widely distributed throughout North America despite being originally introduced in the 1880\'s by Europeans.

-Large, deep-bodied fish. 

-Barbels (whiskers) beside mouth. 

-Back and sides vary from silver to olive-green, brassy or grey. 

-Yellowish belly. 

-Partially scaled cheek and gill cover.

-Length: 30-75 centimetres (12-30 inches) 

-Width: 0.2-3.5 kilograms (0.5-7 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 17.4 kilograms (38.5 pounds)
The Common Carp is able to adapt to a large variety of habitats including warm, shallow, weedy lakes and rivers to urban areas and habitats typically unsuitable for other fish.
The Rainbow Trout were previously only native to the west coast and the rocky mountains. In 1895, they were introduced into the Great Lakes and throughout Ontario.

-Silver body with many small dark spots. 

-Radiating rows of spots over tail. 

-Pink lateral strip often present. 

-More prominent pink stripe on inland Rainbow Trout. 

-White gums and mouth. 

-Long, stocky caudal peduncle.

-Length: 20-60 centimetres (8-24 inches) 

-Weight: 0.5 -6.8 kilograms (1-15 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 18.5 kilograms (40.7 pounds)

Currently, the distribution of the Rainbow Trout is concentrated around the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence river. The habitat of the Rainbow Trout includes cold streams, swift/turbulent water and a range of conditions in rivers, ponds and lakes.
The only native river trout in Ontario, fishing for the Brook Trout is an age old sport that goes back hundreds of years.

-Back is olive-green, brown or black. 

-Belly is silvery or white. 

-Square tail. 

-Mouth extends backwards well beyond the eye. 

-Light markings and spots on dark background, some red and blue.

-Length: 15-40 centimetres (6-16 inches) 

-Weight: 0.45 - 1.36 kilograms (1-3 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 6.6 kilograms (14.5 pounds)

Brook Trout can be found in much of southern Ontario farmland to the larger rivers, ponds and lakes of the North. Within these areas, the fish resides under cover of overhanging branches, logs or rocks, streams with quiet pools between runs of fast water or clear and cold lakes.
A popular recreational fish, the Channel Catfish is a slow growing fish with ages being reported of up to 40.

-Large, elongated body with no scales. 

-4 pairs of dark barbels around the mouth. 

-Pale blue, pale olive or grey back. 

-Tail is more forked than a bullhead's. 

-Grey to yellow to silver-white belly. 

-Lighter sides, often with black-spots.

-Length: 36-53 centimetres (14-21 inches) 

-Weight: 0.9-1.8 kilograms (2-4 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 13.2 kilograms (38.5 pounds)
Channel catfish prefer cooler deeper water with sand, gravel or rubble bottoms. They can often be found in areas of rivers with high current.
The Smallmouth Bass is a popular recreational fish that is only native to some areas of Ontario, but has since been spread throughout Northeastern and Northwestern Ontario.

-Medium-sized, deep-bodied fish. 

-Green to olive back and side. 

-Yellow to white belly. 

-Upper jaw does not extend beyond eye. 

-Shallow notch between dorsal fins.

-Length: 15-20 centimetres (10-20 inches) 

-Weight: 0.5-1.6 kilograms (1-3.5 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 4.5 kilograms (9.8 pounds)

Smallmouth Bass favour rocky areas of lakes, especially points, and will reside over boulder strewn mid-lake shoals. In summer, they may seek shade provided by an overhanging tree, dock or boats. Smallmouth Bass can also be found in similar habitat to trout but with a wider range of temperatures.
The Pumpkinseed is a deep bodied, compressed fish with its defining feature being a red spot on the tip of the gill plate.

-Small, very deep-bodied fish. 

-Wavy, blue-green stripes on sides of head. 

-Ear flap with orange or red spot. 

-Small mouth does not extend to below the middle of the eye. 

-3 anal fin spines. 

-Unnotched dorsal fin with 10 to 11 spins.

-Length: 18-23 centimetres (7-9 inches) 

-Weight: 0.2 kilograms (0.4 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 0.5 kilograms (1.0 pounds)
The preferred habitat of the Pumpkinseed is small lakes and ponds with clear water but can be found in weedy bays of larger lakes.
Lake trout are the largest of the freshwater char and have been reported to live up to 40 years.

-Green, grey, brown or almost black back. 

-White belly and light sides. 

-Light worm-like markings and spot on dark background. 

-Deeply forked tail. 

-White leading edge on lower fins, but no black lines.

-Length: 30-80 centimetres (12-31 inches) 

-Weight: 1-5 kilograms (2-10 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 28.6 kilograms (63.1 pounds)
Most Lake Trout inhabit deep lakes although they can exist in freshwater streams. Lake Trout rarely occur in brackish water.
The Sauger is a freshwater perciform fish that resembles its close relative the walleye.

-Large, elongated body. 

-Grey to brown back with 3-4 darker brown saddles. 

-Lacks the Walleye's white tip on lower tail fin. 

-Distinct blotches or bands on adults. 

-White belly. 

-Spots on dorsal fin. 

-Separate spiny and soft dorsal fin.

-Length: 25-41 centimetres (10-16 inches) 

-Weight: 0.2-0.9 kilograms (0.5-2 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 2.0 kilograms (4.4 pounds)
Sauger enjoy similar habitats to its cousin, the walleye. Their habitats include: murky lakes and large rivers, soft mud bottoms to flooded timber, rubble or bedrock.
The Lake Whitefish is one the most abundant and important commercial freshwater species found in Canada.

-Greenish-brown back. 

-Silvery Sides. 

-Silvery-white belly. 

-Snout overhangs mouth. 

-Deeply forked tail.

-Length: 30-65 centimetres (12-26 inches) 

-Weight: 0.9-1.8 kilograms (2-4 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 6.7 kilograms (14.8 pounds)
Lake Whitefish prefer deep sections of deep lakes and shallow sections of Far North Lakes. During the heat of the summer, whitefish will seek deeper, cooler waters.
Lake Ontario once held the world\'s greatest population of Atlantic Salmon before they vanished in the late 19th century.

-White mouth and gums. 

-No spots on tail. 

-Few large, black spots on gill cover. 

-Dark-coloured pectoral fins. 

-Dark-coloured pectoral fins.

-Length: 25-70 centimeters (10-28 inches) 

-Weight: 3.6-5.4 kilograms (7.9-11.9 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 11.02 kilograms (24.3 pounds)

Typically, Atlantic Salmon spend most of their life at sea but return to freshwater when they spawn. However in Lake Ontario, Atlantic Salmon do not return to the sea and instead lived solely in the lake, relying on connecting freshwater streams to lay eggs.
Lake Sturgeon are a long lived species and are the largest fish species in Ontario.

-Underslung mouth. 

-Whiskers. 

-Bony plates on sides.

-Length: 90-145 centimeters (3-5 feet) 

-Weight: 4.5-36 kilograms (10-80 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 76.2 kilograms (168 pounds)
Lake Sturgeon inhabit larger river and lake systems, usually in depths of 5 to 9 meters.
Brown Trout are a non-native species that were originally introduce from Europe around 1913 but are now considered to be naturalized.

-Brown back. 

-Silvery or pale brown sides with dark spots. 

-White belly. 

-White mouth and gums. 

-Only salmon/trout with orange on adipose fin. 

-Leading anal fin ray extends the length of the fin.

-Length: 20-60 centimetres (8-24 inches) 

-Weight: 0.5-4.5 kilograms (1-9.5 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 15.6 kilograms (34.4 pounds)
Brown Trout can be found in pools or ponds fed by streams. They can also reside in quiet, calm waters to turbulent and fast flowing streams.
The Splake is a hatchery made cross between a Brook Trout and a Lake Trout.

-Slightly deep-bodied. 

-Hybrid of Brook Trout and Lake Trout, between them in size. 

-Tricolour fins. 

-Light spots on a dark background, some red spots. 

-Slightly forked tail.

-Length: 25-46 centimetres (10-18 inches) 

-Weight: 0.45-1.35 kilograms (1-3 pounds) 

-Ontario Record: 9.4 kilograms (20.71 pounds)
Splake are stocked throughout much of Ontario and need a year-round supply of cold, clear water. They reside in typical trout habitat and can tolerate marginal trout habitat (low pH waters).
The Bluegill is one of the most popular panfish in North America.

-Small, very deep-bodied fish. 

-Back and sides are green to brown with fain, dark bars. 

-Belly is silver to yellow. 

-Black spot at rear end of dorsal fin. 

-3 anal fin spines.

-Length: 15-22.5 centimetres (6-9 inches) 

-Weight: 200 grams (0.4 pounds) 

-Ontario Record: 800 grams (1.8 pounds)
Bluegills are can be found in many of Ontario southern waters. Their habitat includes warmer lakes and ponds, slow-moving vegetated streams, and clear waters with some weed growth.
Coho Salmon are a Pacific coast fish that were originally introduced in the later 1870s.

-Deep-bodied but thin from side to side. 

-Blue or green back. 

-Silvery sides. 

-White belly. 

-Smaller than Chinook salmon. 

-Dark mouth-light grey gums.

-Length: 30-75 centimetres (12-30 inches) 

-Weight: 2.25-4.5 kilograms (5-10 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 13 kilograms (28.6 pounds)

Coho Salmon are native to the North Pacific Ocean and have been introduced into the Great Lakes. Coho Salmon spend most of the year in cold waters of the Great Lakes but return to tributary streams to spawn.
Chinook Salmon are a Pacific coast fish that were originally introduced in the later 1870s.

-Blue or green back. 

-Silvery sides. 

-White belly. 

-Spotted tail. 

-Black mouth and gums. 

-Elongated, moderately deep-bodied fish.

-Length: 30-100 centimetres (12-39 inches) 

-Weight: 3.1 -6.8 kilograms (7-15 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 21 kilograms (46.4 pounds)
Chinook Salmon spends most of the year in the cold waters of the Great Lakes but return to tributary streams to spawn.
Black Crappie is a recreational fish whose range extends across North America.

-Small, deep-bodied fish. 

-Silver with blue or green iridescence and irregular mosaic of distinct black blotches. 

-7 to 8 dorsal fin spines. 

-6 to 7 anal fin spines. 

-Large mouth extends below middle of eye.

-Length: 18-25 centimetres (7-10 inches) 

-Weight: 0.23-0.45 kilograms (0.5-1.0 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 1.7 kilograms (3.8 pounds)

Black Crappie can be found throughout southern Ontario, including protected bays of the southern Great Lakes and in northwestern Ontario. Black Crappie prefer warm, clear, vegetated lakes, ponds and rivers with little current.
The Lake Herring is a commercial and recreational fish that is also known as the Cisco.

-Silver sides. 

-Mouth not overhung by snout. 

-Mouth ends before middle of eye.

-Length: 20â€“30 centimetres (8â€“12 inches) 

-Weight: 0.34â€“0.570 kilograms (0.75 â€“ 1.25 pounds) 

-Ontario record: 1.96 kilograms (4.33 pounds)
The Lake Herring lives in the open waters of lakes and rivers to the coastal waters of Hudson Bay.
